column3: The Chhattisgarh government's proposal to add egg in the Mid-day Meal Scheme to fight malnutrition in students was criticised by social organisations and the BJP opposition. "This is a move to promote non-vegetarian food. There are other vegetarian options to fight...malnourishment," said an opposer. The government had reached out to the group through a committee, however, no solution was found.

column2: 1.14 lakh affected by floods in Meghalaya's West Garo Hills
column3: At least 1.14 lakh people in 154 villages have been affected after rainfall and rising waters of two rivers led to floods in Meghalaya's West Garo Hills district, officials said on Monday. The low-lying areas of the state's capital Shillong have also been flooded. Efforts are on to evacuate the flood victims and take them to safer locations, officials added.

column2: Air India, MTNL among 56 sick CPSEs with negative net worth
column3: The government on Monday said 56 of its Central Public Sector Enterprises (CPSEs) were sick, having negative net worths. These loss-making public enterprises include Air India, MTNL, Bharat Coking Coal, Hindustan Cables, and Indian Drugs & Pharmaceuticals. In 2017-18, the enterprises had a collective net worth of negative ₹88,556 crore, with a total accumulated loss of ₹1.32 lakh crore.

column2: Hema has picked broom only in films: Dharmendra to fan on viral video
column3: After Hema Malini was criticised over a viral video of her sweeping Parliament premises, her husband Dharmendra responded to a fan who asked if she has actually picked a broom in life. "Haan films main, mujhe bhi anaadi lag rahi thi," he replied. Dharmendra added he was good at using a broom since he helped his mother with household chores.

column2: Sameera Reddy shares first photo of her newborn daughter
column3: Actress Sameera Reddy on Monday shared the first photo of her daughter who was born on Friday. "This little girl gave me the strength of wild horses. She wanted me to find myself again. She knew I was lost and she showed me the way," she wrote. Sameera added, "We prayed for a #babygirl and we are #blessed!"

column2: SRK to be awarded honorary doctorate at Indian Film Fest of Melbourne
column3: Australian University La Trobe will award actor Shah Rukh Khan with an honorary doctorate at the Indian Film Festival of Melbourne on August 9. It's the first Australian University to award Khan with an Honorary Doctor of Letters. "I would like to sincerely thank La Trobe for choosing to recognise my achievements in such a humbling way," the actor said.

column2: Awarding England 6 runs on overthrow a clear mistake: Simon Taufel
column3: Ex-umpire Simon Taufel has said awarding England six runs on overthrow in World Cup final was "a clear mistake". The five-time ICC best umpire award winner added that England should have been awarded five runs as per the rules. He added that Ben Stokes and Adil Rashid had not crossed for their second run at instant of Martin Guptill's throw.

column2: ICC announces Team of World Cup, two Indians feature on the list
column3: The ICC on Monday named the Team of the 2019 World Cup, which features two Indians, opener Rohit Sharma and fast bowler Jasprit Bumrah. New Zealand skipper Kane Williamson, who won the player of the tournament award, has been named the captain of the team. The 12-member team includes four players from the tournament-winning side, England.

column2: K'taka MLAs write to Mumbai Police again, seek protection from Cong
column3: The 14 Karnataka rebel MLAs, staying at a Mumbai hotel, wrote to the police again, seeking protection from Congress leaders who may try to meet them. "We have absolutely no intention to meet Shri Mallikarjun Kharge ji or Ghulam Nabi Azad ji or any Congress dignitaries or functionaries from Maharashtra and Karnataka...we anticipate a serious threat from them," they said.

column2: SC to hear PIL on decriminalising abortion, sends notice to Centre
column3: Supreme Court on Monday issued a notice to Centre while agreeing to hear a PIL by three women seeking directions to decriminalise abortion, so that women have the choice of reproduction. The PIL said restrictions and exceptions in Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act violate women's rights. The petition was filed by a teacher, a digital marketeer and a PR executive.

column2: Kalraj Mishra appointed HP Governor, Acharya Devvrat moved to Gujarat
column3: Senior BJP leader and former Union Minister Kalraj Mishra was on Monday appointed as the Governor of Himachal Pradesh, replacing Acharya Devvrat, who has been transferred and appointed as the Governor of Gujarat. A Rashtrapati Bhavan press communique said the appointments of Mishra and Devvrat will come into effect from the dates they will assume charge of their respective offices.

column2: Suspecting 'character', man kills girlfriend by crushing face: Police
column3: A 19-year-old aspiring model was allegedly killed by her boyfriend on suspicion of her "character" in Maharashtra's Nagpur, police said, adding that the accused has been arrested. A police official said they received information on Saturday morning about the body of a woman found on a highway with her face crushed. The boyfriend allegedly suspected her "closeness" with some youths.

column2: Delhi govt to give free safety kits to sanitation workers: Kejriwal
column3: Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal on Monday said his government will give free safety kits to sanitation workers. Speaking at a Delhi Jal Board (DJB) workshop, Kejriwal said he feels dejected to hear about the deaths of sanitation workers. DJB Vice Chairman Dinesh Mohaniya said the one-day workshop was organised to make sanitation workers aware about the use of safety kits.

column2: Don't use 'My Lord' while addressing judges: Rajasthan HC to lawyers
column3: Rajasthan High Court has asked lawyers to stop addressing judges as "My lord" and "Your Lordship" in order to "honour the mandate of equality enshrined in the Constitution". A bench of justices in 2014 had observed that it wasn't compulsory to call judges "My Lord", "Your Lordship" or "Your Honour". "We only say address us respectfully," the bench had said.

column2: Iran threatens to return to situation before nuclear deal
column3: Iran will return to the situation before its nuclear deal with world powers unless European countries fulfil their obligations, the spokesman for Iran's nuclear agency, Behrouz Kamalvandi, has said. He added that under the 2015 deal, Iran gave much more than what it received because the other side, particularly after the US withdrawal from the deal, forgot its obligations.

column2: Hello Taxi's ex-CEO alleges ₹1,000 crore fraud by promoters
column3: Delhi-based cab aggregator Hello Taxi's former CEO Saroj Mahapatra alleged that the company's promoters have siphoned off investors' money to the tune of ₹1,000 crore. He said that he and senior company officials are wrongly named in the fraud. Hello Taxi, which operates a multi-level marketing scheme and offers high returns, owes a huge amount of money to investors.

column2: Vinesh Phogat wins gold medal at Yasar Dogu International
column3: Indian wrestler Vinesh Phogat on Sunday beat Russia's Ekaterina Poleshchuk to win the gold medal at Yasar Dogu International in the 53 kg category. Phogat, who was the third wrestler to win gold in the women's competition for India, tweeted, "Strong performance over the last couple of days at the #YasarDogu here in Istanbul."

column2: Mochizuki first Japanese player to win boy's Grand Slam title
column3: Shintaro Mochizuki on Sunday became the first Japanese player to win a boy's Grand Slam title, beating Carlos Gimeno Valero of Spain 6-3, 6-2 in the Wimbledon final. The 16-year-old, who was playing just his third grass-court tournament, said he had learned a lot from his compatriot, 2014 US Open finalist Kei Nishikori.

column2: Queen sends congratulatory message to WC-winning Eng team
column3: Queen Elizabeth II sent her congratulations to the England team after they beat New Zealand to lift their maiden World Cup title on Sunday. "Prince Philip and I send our warmest congratulations to the England Men's Cricket team after such a thrilling victory in today's World Cup final," wrote The Royal Family official Twitter account.

column2: Sebastian Vettel apologises to Max Verstappen, admits mistake
column3: Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel apologised to Red Bull's Max Verstappen immediately after Sunday's British Grand Prix after he had rammed into the Red Bull car after the Dutchman had passed him. Following the incident, Vettel had to make a pit stop while Verstappen rejoined the race and finished fifth, missing out on a possible podium finish.

column2: Oracle loses court appeal against $10 bn US govt contract
column3: US-based Oracle has lost its legal challenge against US Pentagon's $10-billion contract for 'JEDI' cloud infrastructure, which it alleged unfairly favoured Amazon. The Federal Claims Court said there were no "organisational conflicts of interest" and because Oracle didn't meet bid's criteria, it can't allege prejudice in the bidding. The US can now award the contract to Amazon or Microsoft.

column2: Appalled to learn of Sidhu's resignation: Shatrughan Sinha
column3: Congress leader Shatrughan Sinha on Sunday took to Twitter to say that he was appalled to learn of Navjot Singh Sidhu's resignation from the Punjab Cabinet. Sinha said, "He has been a...talented and popular sportsman/politician...a wonderful human being and...a dear friend." "[W]e cannot question his decision, one would...pray for remedial measures soon towards...this unfortunate move," he added.

column2: Centre issued 10 advisories to WB in just 10 days: TMC leader
column3: Accusing the Centre of targeting West Bengal government, TMC leader Sudip Bandyopadhyay on Monday said that the Centre has issued "10 advisories" to the state government in "just 10 days". He added that this is "hurting the parliamentary democratic system". "Why the West Bengal government is being targeted? We will not allow it," the TMC leader said.

column2: Worst not yet over in auto sector: Mahindra MD on sale slump
column3: The worst isn't yet over for the auto industry amid a slowdown in sales, Mahindra and Mahindra's MD Pawan Goenka said. "I suggest...government remove the cess on small cars and keep 17% single cess rate for large cars for next four-six months," he added. Diesel vehicle costs are expected to rise after BS-VI emission norms come into effect in 2020.

column2: Violence erupts in West Bengal, train services disrupted
column3: Violence broke out in West Bengal's Kankinara on Monday following which the locals disrupted train services in the Barrackpore-Naihati division of Eastern Railway (ER), an official said. The services were affected for about two hours and 16 local trains were delayed, the official added. Miscreants hurled bombs, prompting the administration to deploy the RAF to control the situation, he said.

column2: Girl dies after fire breaks out in hostel room in Telangana
column3: A Class 4 girl died of suffocation and burn injuries after a fire broke out in a hostel room in Telangana's Khammam, a fire official said. He added that the room was engulfed in a fire triggered by a short circuit. He said that the room had only one exit which made it difficult for the children to rush out.

column2: Infosys Q1 profit rises 5.3% at ₹3,802 cr, shares hit record high
column3: India's second-largest IT services firm Infosys has reported a 5.3% year-on-year rise in profit in the quarter ended June at ₹3,802 crore, beating market estimates. The company's shares rose by 7.2% on Monday, hitting an all-time high. Its first-quarter revenue grew by 14% to ₹21,803 crore from the year-ago period.

column2: Wholesale inflation falls to 23-month low of 2.02% in June
column3: India's wholesale inflation, measured by the Wholesale Price Index (WPI), declined to a 23-month low of 2.02% in June, government data showed on Monday. The fall was driven by a decline in the prices of vegetables, manufactured products, fuel and power items. The inflation fell for the second time in a row, from 2.45% in the month of May 2019.

column2: Don't take up sport, die at 60 fat & happy: Neesham after final loss
column3: After losing the 2019 World Cup against England on boundary count, New Zealand all-rounder Jimmy Neesham tweeted, "That hurts. Hopefully there's a day or two over the next decade where I don't think about that last half hour." He added, "Kids, don't take up sport. Take up baking or something. Die at 60 really fat and happy."

column2: We all aged a year in that Super Over: NZ PM after team's defeat
column3: After England beat New Zealand in the 2019 World Cup final on Sunday, New Zealand Prime Minster Jacinda Ardern said, "I think as a nation we all aged a year in that Super Over." "That was undeniably an incredible game...Congratulations to England. And to the Black Caps, I feel nothing but pride. What a team," she added.

column2: Karnataka coalition government to take floor test on Thursday
column3: The Congress-JD(S) coalition government in Karnataka will take the floor test on Thursday, former Chief Minister of Karnataka and Congress leader Siddaramaiah said on Monday. This comes after several MLAs of the coalition government submitted their resignations to the Assembly Speaker. The resignations by the MLAs have not been accepted by the Assembly Speaker.

column2: It is kind of silly: GoT's Nikolaj on criticism against final season
column3: 'Game of Thrones' actor Nikolaj Coster-Waldau has reacted to the criticism received by the show's final season. "For anyone to...think that the two creators of this show are not the most passionate...and to for a second think that they didn't spend the last 10 years thinking about how they were gonna end it, is kinda silly," he said.

column2: England is a winner because of stupid f**king rules: Anurag Kashyap
column3: Filmmaker Anurag Kashyap, while criticising the ICC after New Zealand lost the 2019 World Cup final to England over boundary rule, tweeted, "England is a winner because of stupid f**king rules...New Zealand is a true winner." "@ICC has made cricket such a batsmen game...It's all about the batsmen scores and the wickets are treated like the lower caste," he added.

column2: Apple to stop iPhone SE, iPhone 6, 6 Plus, 6s Plus India sales: Report
column3: Apple will reportedly stop selling its lower-priced smartphones iPhone SE, iPhone 6, 6 Plus and 6s Plus in India. The company reportedly does not want to chase volumes by discounting at the cost of profit in the country. These models will reportedly be phased out to increase the average selling price of iPhones in India and boost profit and revenue.

column2: I have no issues with him: Punjab CM after Sidhu's resignation
column3: After Navjot Singh Sidhu resigned as Minister from Punjab Cabinet, Chief Minister Amarinder Singh said, "I have no issues with him, I had in fact given him a very important portfolio after the reshuffle. It was his decision to quit the Cabinet." "I will go through his resignation letter and then see what is to be done," he added.

column2: Swiggy looking to raise $500 mn in funding round: Report
column3: Food delivery app Swiggy is reportedly in talks with South Korean funds including Korea Investment Partners, Mirae Asset Management and others for a $500 million funding round. Swiggy's largest investor, South African internet giant Naspers, may reportedly lead the round. The round is said to value Swiggy at around $4 billion.

column2: SC dismisses Asaram's bail plea in sexual assault case
column3: The Supreme Court has dismissed the bail plea of self-styled godman Asaram in connection with a sexual assault case lodged against him in Gujarat. The SC bench said the trial needs to be completed first. Solicitor General Tushar Mehta informed the bench that the trial in the case was going on and that 210 witnesses were yet to be examined.

column2: Will cut business ties with US firms that sell arms to Taiwan: China
column3: China's government and companies will cut business ties with US firms involved in selling arms to Taiwan, China's foreign ministry has said. However, the ministry did not specify which companies would be affected. This comes after China threatened to impose sanctions on US firms involved in a deal to sell $2.2-billion worth of tanks, missiles and related equipment to Taiwan.

column2: Zidane leaves Canada training camp as his brother passes away
column3: Real Madrid coach Zinedine Zidane left the team's training camp in Canada after his elder brother Farid passed away aged 54. The club confirmed the news on social media and shared a picture of players and staff holding a minute's silence in Montreal. Assistant manager David Bettoni will take charge of training until Zidane returns.

column2: US Army to test robotic combat vehicles in 2020
column3: The US Army will start testing robotic combat vehicles in 2020 which soldiers will control from the back of modified Bradley Fighting Vehicles. The upgraded Bradleys, called Mission Enabler Technologies-Demonstrators (MET-Ds), have a remote turret for 25 mm main gun, 360-degree cameras and crew stations with touchscreens. Initial testing will include two MET-Ds and four robotic combat vehicles.

column2: Cong is filled with 'fake Gandhis': Shivraj Singh Chouhan
column3: Former Madhya Pradesh CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan criticised the Congress saying that the party is filled with "fake Gandhis" and that's why people are "rejecting" it in all states. Commenting on Rahul Gandhi's resignation as Congress President, Chouhan said Rahul left his party as he was unable to run it "efficiently". He added Rahul "escaped" from the party President's post.

column2: Have sent resignation as Punjab minister to CM: Navjot Sidhu
column3: Cricketer-turned-politician Navjot Singh Sidhu on Monday said that he has sent his resignation as a Punjab Cabinet minister to CM Captain Amarinder Singh and it has been delivered to his official residence. Sidhu had earlier submitted his resignation letter to Congress leader Rahul Gandhi instead of CM Singh. In June, Sidhu's portfolio was changed after a Cabinet reshuffle.

column2: Pune-based agritech startup Ecozen raises Series A funding
column3: Pune-based agritech startup Ecozen has raised an undisclosed amount of funding in Series A round from Hyderabad-based Caspian and the Hivos-Triodos Fund. Mumbai-based investment firm Omnivore, which originally invested in Ecozen in 2015, also participated in this round. Founded in 2010 by three IIT Kharagpur alumni, Ecozen provides renewable energy based solutions to increase farmer income.

column2: Muslims with 50 wives, 1,050 kids 'animalistic': BJP MLA
column3: BJP MLA Surendra Singh said that Muslims who have 50 wives and 1,050 children possess "animalistic tendency". Singh added, in 2024, when the RSS will complete 100 years, India would be declared a Hindu Rashtra. He termed West Bengal as 'Lanka' and said that half of Bengal had been "destroyed" and the remaining would be finished after the Assembly elections.

column2: NDMC to rename 31 schools after ex-PM Atal Bihari Vajpayee
column3: The New Delhi Municipal Council (NDMC) has issued an order to change the names of 31 NDMC Schools after ex-PM Atal Bihari Vajpayee. It has decided to rename schools from 'Nagar Palika School' to 'Atal Adarsh Vidyalaya' from the academic session 2019-2020. The move has been made to improve "enrolment" and the "public perception" of the schools, the NDMC said.

column2: Inspired from TV show, Delhi man fakes robbery to fund wedding
column3: Delhi Police arrested two people on Sunday for staging a robbery to steal ₹10 lakh from the main accused's employer to fund his upcoming wedding after being inspired by television show 'Crime Patrol'. The incident occurred on Thursday when the main accused claimed that two bike-borne men stole the cash. However, investigation by police revealed contradictions in the accused's story.

column2: 8 suspended, notice to 3 for negligence in cattle care in UP
column3: Uttar Pradesh Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath on Sunday suspended eight officials and issued show-cause notices to three others for negligence after 35 cattle were found dead in a temporary shelter in Prayagraj. Addressing the state's District Magistrates through video call, Yogi warned criminal proceedings in the future. He had earlier asked officials to ensure that cow shelters are self-reliant.

column2: 4 dead, around 18 lakh affected due to floods in Bihar
column3: At least four people have died and around 18 lakh were affected due to floods in nine districts of Bihar, an official report said. The report added that five rivers of the state are flowing above the danger level due to torrential rains in the catchment areas bordering Nepal. CM Nitish Kumar conducted an aerial survey of the flood-affected areas.

column2: Iran ready to talk if US lifts sanctions: President Rouhani
column3: Iran is ready to hold talks with the US if it lifts sanctions and returns to the 2015 nuclear deal it quit last year, Iranian President Hassan Rouhani said on Sunday. "We have always believed in talks," Rouhani added. US President Donald Trump's administration has said it is open to negotiations with Iran.

column2: England win World Cup for first time for hitting more boundaries
column3: England won the World Cup for the first time due to hitting more boundaries after tied scores in World Cup history's first-ever Super Over forced a boundary count-back. The match went into Super Over wherein both the teams scored 15 each after hitting 241 runs apiece in their respective 50 overs. England scored 26 boundaries while New Zealand hit 17.

column2: World Cup to be decided on Super Over for the first time ever
column3: The 2019 World Cup final will be decided in Super Over after New Zealand dismissed England for 241 runs in their 50 overs. Needing 15 runs off the last over, England scored 14 runs and lost two wickets. New Zealand had put up 241/8 in their 50 overs. This is the first time that World Cup final has been tied.

column2: New Zealand-born Stokes named Man of 2019 WC final vs New Zealand
column3: England all-rounder Ben Stokes, who scored 84*(98) in the 2019 World Cup final against New Zealand, was named Man of the Final. The 28-year-old, who was born in New Zealand's Christchurch, became the first-ever England player to win the Man of the World Cup Final award. Stokes also hit eight of England's 15 runs in the Super Over.

column2: Williamson second captain to win Player of the World Cup award
column3: New Zealand captain Kane Williamson, who led Kiwis to 2019 World Cup final, has been named Player of the World Cup. The 28-year-old became the second captain in World Cup history to win the award after late New Zealand captain Martin Crowe in 1992 edition. Williamson scored 578 runs in ten 2019 World Cup matches at an average of 82.57.

column2: Djokovic defeats Federer to win 2nd straight Wimbledon title
column3: World number one Novak Djokovic defeated world number three Roger Federer in fifth-set tie-break on Sunday to win his second straight Wimbledon title. Overall, it was Djokovic's fifth Wimbledon title and 16th Grand Slam title. The 32-year-old Serbian has become the fourth man after Federer, Rafael Nadal and Rod Laver to win four major titles since turning 30.

column2: ISRO calls off 'Chandrayaan 2' launch for today after technical snag
column3: The Indian Space Research Organisation on Monday called off the launch of India's second Moon mission 'Chandrayaan 2' for today "as a measure of abundant precaution" after a technical snag was observed in launch vehicle system at T-56 minute. "Revised launch date will be announced later," ISRO tweeted. The launch for 'Chandrayaan 2' was scheduled for 2:51 am today.

column2: 6 Army men among 7 dead in Himachal building collapse
column3: At least seven people, of which six were Army men, died and several more were injured after a multi-storey building housing a small eatery on Kumarhatti-Nahan road in Himachal Pradesh's Solan district collapsed on Sunday. Seven Army personnel are still feared trapped. The wife of the restaurant owner was also among the seven people killed in the incident.

column2: Husband of BJP MLA's daughter who released video beaten up
column3: The husband of BJP MLA Rajesh Mishra's daughter Sakshi Mishra was allegedly beaten up by some people at Allahabad High Court on Monday. Sakshi had sought police protection and had released a video accusing her father of threatening her life following her marriage to the Dalit man. Sakshi's father had said the man was "nine years older than her".

column2: Pooja Batra confirms marrying Nawab Shah in secret wedding ceremony
column3: Actress Pooja Batra has confirmed that she got married to actor Nawab Shah in a secret wedding ceremony. "[We] exchanged vows in Delhi, with only our families in attendance...We had an Arya Samaj wedding, and we'll register our marriage this week," she said. Earlier, reports of their marriage surfaced after videos shared by the couple showed Pooja wearing bridal choora.

column2: Vicky shares note by fan who joined Indian Navy after watching Uri
column3: Actor Vicky Kaushal took to his Instagram story to share a message by a fan, who joined the Indian Navy after being inspired by his film 'Uri: The Surgical Strike'. "Thank you for making such a masterpiece for it will remain forever in our mind and spirit," the fan wrote in the note sent to the film's director Aditya Dhar.

column2: I'll be apologising to NZ for rest of my life: Stokes on deflected four
column3: Talking about the overthrow incident in last over of 2019 World Cup final, England all-rounder Ben Stokes said he told New Zealand captain Kane Williamson that he'd be apologising to them for the rest of his life. The ball had raced to the boundary for four overthrows after deflecting off Stokes' bat. The 28-year-old was named man of the final.

column2: Twitter to begin testing 'hide replies' feature in Canada
column3: Twitter is rolling out the 'hide replies' feature to its users in Canada for testing purpose. When users look at the replies, they'll be able to select any of them and choose "hide reply" option. These tweets won't be fully removed from Twitter as users will be able to tap on a grey icon to view hidden replies.

column2: Uttar Pradesh officials consider to list Azam Khan as land mafia
column3: Uttar Pradesh's Rampur district administration is considering listing Samajwadi Party leader Azam Khan's name under the "land mafia" category on the state government's "anti-bhoo mafia" (anti-land mafia) portal. Khan has over 30 cases, mostly linked to grabbing of either government or farmer land. The portal was set up by CM Yogi Adityanath after he took power in UP in 2017.

column2: Go back to countries you came from: Trump tells Congresswomen
column3: US President Donald Trump on Sunday told a group of Congresswomen to "go back" to the "totally broken and crime infested" countries they came from rather than "loudly and viciously telling the people of the US" how to run the government. Trump appeared to be referring to US Congresswomen Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Ilhan Omar, Ayanna Pressley and Rashida Tlaib.

column2: 9 killed as plane crashes during skydiving trip in Sweden
column3: Nine Swedes were killed after a plane crashed during a skydiving trip in northern Sweden, authorities said. The plane designed to carry parachutists crashed on an island in the Ume river shortly after takeoff from Umeå airport. Sweden's PM Stefan Löfven said the government was in close contact with the relevant authorities as they investigate the cause of the crash.

column2: BJP will win over 65 seats in Jharkhand, says JP Nadda
column3: Ahead of the forthcoming Assembly elections in Jharkhand, BJP national working President JP Nadda on Sunday said that the saffron party will win more than 65 seats in the state. He added that the "double-engine" (the Centre and the state government) was providing the much-needed growth to the state. Nadda also appreciated CM Raghubar Das-led government's performance in Jharkhand.

column2: Delhi govt should work in harmony with Centre: Sitharaman
column3: Union Minister Nirmala Sitharaman said that the Delhi government should work in harmony with the Centre and the municipal corporations for the development of the national capital. She said blaming the Centre and municipal corporations for creating hindrance in development work is "wrong". Sitharaman also accused the Delhi government of not being concerned about the cleaning of Yamuna river.

column2: It's good Navjot Sidhu resigned: Union Minister Som Parkash
column3: Union Minister Som Parkash said that it was good that Navjot Singh Sidhu resigned as Cabinet Minister from CM Captain Amarinder Singh-led government in Punjab. He added, "It's the first time in the country that a minister's portfolio was changed and he resigned." In June, Sidhu was given Power and New and Renewable Energy Sources portfolios after a Cabinet reshuffle.

column2: Speaker doesn't have right to disqualify anybody: Yeddyurappa
column3: BJP Karnataka President BS Yeddyurappa on Sunday said the Speaker doesn't have the right to disqualify anybody because of the Supreme Court's decision. The court had directed the Speaker to maintain status quo on the rebel MLAs resignations until July 16. Earlier, Congress leader DK Shivakumar said the MLAs who vote against government in Confidence Motion will lose their membership.

column2: Dead patient's kin attack 3 resident doctors in Mumbai hospital
column3: Three resident doctors and security guards of Mumbai's Nair Hospital were allegedly abused and attacked by the kin of a patient who died during treatment, police said. The relatives also damaged the hospital property, the police added. Condemning the attack, Maharashtra Association of Resident Doctors (MARD) has urged the government to make necessary changes to ensure the protection of doctors.

column2: Assam floods death toll rises to 11; over 26 lakh affected
column3: The death toll in the Assam floods, which have affected over 26 lakh people, rose to 11 after four more people were killed on Sunday. Barpeta district is the worst hit with 7.35 lakh people affected, followed by Morigaon with 3.5 lakh people affected. The India Meteorological Department has predicted more rainfall in the state for the next 24 hours.

column2: India says Deloitte misreading law against call for 5-yr ban: Report
column3: The government reportedly told a tribunal that Deloitte was misreading law by arguing that the case against it should be dismissed as its term at IL&FS unit IFIN had ended when the fraud was alleged. "Fraud continuing till date on account of errant past auditor...can be covered under law," it added. India is seeking a 5-year ban on Deloitte India.

column2: No 'Greta effect' on Lufthansa's passenger numbers, says CEO
column3: Lufthansa expects the number of its passengers to rise four per cent this year, not seeing any "Greta effect" on booking levels, the German airline's CEO Carsten Spohr said. This follows activists led by 16-year-old Swedish activist Greta Thunberg boycotting air travel amid carbon emission concerns. "Climate change discussions aren't causing restraint with bookings. People want to fly," he said.

column2: Gangwal limited his financial risk: IndiGo Co-Founder Bhatia
column3: IndiGo Co-Founder Rahul Bhatia has said that while he had extended personal loans to finance IndiGo from fiscal 2006-10, Co-Founder Rakesh Gangwal remained in "safe harbour" with equity exposure below ₹15 crore. He added that his IGE Group and Gangwal had a financial risk ratio of 80:1. Gangwal attempted to de-risk himself and pushed for IndiGo's sale, Bhatia further alleged.

column2: A man was masturbating on video call, alleges Mumbai scriptwriter
column3: A Mumbai scriptwriter has alleged that a man flashed his private parts at her and also masturbated during a video call on Skype. "I was unable to see the face of the person...After taking screenshots to lodge a complaint, I disconnected the call," she stated in her police complaint. On Saturday morning, a case was registered in the matter.

column2: RJ Stutee claims RWA president harassed her for coming home late
column3: RJ Stutee has alleged that RWA president Micky Bedi and his wife harassed her and refused to let the guard open the gate as she was coming back late due to work. "This is a major security issue...My parents are worried,” Stutee, who stays in GK, Delhi tweeted. She also shared pictures of the police complaint filed by her mother.

column2: Woman promoting porn website tries to invade World Cup final pitch
column3: A woman promoting her son's porn website attempted to invade the pitch during England-New Zealand 2019 World Cup final at Lord's Cricket Ground on Sunday. The security guards stopped the streaker near the boundary ropes and dragged her out of the ground. Notably, her son's girlfriend had invaded the pitch during the Champions League final in June.

column2: NZ set same target for Eng which first-time winners SL got in 1996
column3: New Zealand have set a target of 242 for England in the final of 2019 World Cup at Lord's Cricket Ground on Sunday. In the final of the 1996 World Cup, Sri Lanka were also given a target of 242 by Australia. Sri Lanka chased down the target in 46.2 overs to win the World Cup for first time.

column2: AI system to warn about spoilers in online reviews developed
column3: Researchers have developed an AI-based system called 'SpoilerNet' that figures out spoilers in online reviews of books and TV shows and warns about them to the users. The system can be used to build a browser extension to shield people from spoilers. The researchers collected over 1.3 million book reviews annotated with spoiler tags by book reviewers for the system.

column2: K'taka MLA reaches Mumbai day after announcing resignation withdrawal
column3: A day after announcing the withdrawal of his resignation, Karnataka Congress MLA MTB Nagaraj on Sunday arrived at the Mumbai hotel where 14 rebel MLAs of Congress-JD(S) coalition are staying. Nagaraj was accompanied by BJP MLA R Ashok at the hotel. Following the development, Karnataka BJP President BS Yeddyurappa said he will request CM HD Kumaraswamy to resign immediately.

column2: BL Santosh appointed BJP's National General Secretary (Organisation)
column3: Bharatiya Janata Party has appointed BL Santosh as its National General Secretary (Organisation). Santosh, previously the party's Joint General Secretary (Organisation), took over from Ramlal, who went back to the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh after serving for one of the longest terms in the key party post. The BJP said in a statement that Santosh's appointment comes into immediate effect.

column2: 2 dead, 23 rescued in three-storey building collapse in HP's Solan
column3: As many as two bodies have been recovered and 23 people have been rescued after a three-storey building collapsed on Kumarhatti-Nahan road in Himachal Pradesh's Solan district due to heavy rains on Sunday. Out of the 23 people, 18 are Army men and five are civilians. Fourteen people are still feared trapped as rescue operations continue.

column2: BJP leader's nephew does stunts in sports car in Delhi, video viral
column3: A video of a Nissan GT-R sports car performing dangerous stunts near the Parliament in Delhi on Saturday at around 4 am has gone viral. Police said the sports car was being driven by Sarvesh Sindhu, the nephew of Haryana Finance Minister Captain Abhimanyu. The sports car owned by Sarvesh was found at a farmhouse in Delhi's Kapashera area.

column2: 2 killed, 26 injured as joyride collapses in Ahmedabad adventure park
column3: At least two people were killed and 26 others injured when a joyride at an adventure park in Ahmedabad's Kankaria collapsed on Sunday. The injured were rushed to the LG Hospital. Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) Commissioner Vijay Nehra said, "Police along with the FSL team is investigating the matter."

column2: Bullet train passengers may be charged for extra baggage: Report
column3: The National High Speed Rail Corporation (NHSRCL) executing the Mumbai-Ahmedabad bullet train project plans to charge travellers for the bags they check in. "Basically, the idea is to discourage passengers from carrying heavy luggage," the NHSRCL said. Every coach is said to contain sufficient space for hand baggage and the last coach will have space for the extra check-in luggage.

column2: Karnataka woman falls into pond while shooting TikTok video, dies
column3: A 20-year-old woman from Karnataka lost her life after falling into a farm pond while trying to enact a scene from a movie for a TikTok video. Her father told the police that the incident occurred when Mala, a final year BA student, went out to get cattle fodder. Mala's college principal said she was an aspiring actor.

column2: Internship at White House worst career advice I've received: Lewinsky
column3: American television personality Monica Lewinsky today tweeted that "an internship at the White House will be amazing on your resume" is the worst career advice she's ever received. Over 20 years ago, former US President Bill Clinton and Lewinsky, a White House intern, were named in a sex scandal. Clinton was impeached by the House for lying about the affair.

column2: Twitter spat between Mazumdar-Shaw, Pai on Godrej's hate crime remark
column3: A Twitter spat broke out between Biocon MD Kiran Mazumdar-Shaw and Infosys' ex-Director Mohandas Pai over Godrej Group's Adi Godrej's "Rising hate crimes can damage growth" remark on Saturday. As Mazumdar-Shaw tweeted, "well spoken", Pai said she's falling for a "fake narrative". "He says economy isn't in good shape n (and) we shd (should) not be in denial," Mazumdar-Shaw responded.

column2: Vijay Shankar to undergo fitness tests at NCA for injured toe
column3: All-rounder Vijay Shankar is set to undergo tests at National Cricket Academy (NCA) in Bengaluru to determine the extent of his toe injury which he suffered during 2019 World Cup. Shankar was hit by a yorker from Jasprit Bumrah during practice. Shankar scored 58 runs and took two wickets in the 2019 World Cup before being replaced by Mayank Agarwal.

column2: Hungary thrash South Korea 64-0 in water polo World C'ships
column3: Hungary set the record for the largest margin of victory in a water polo game at the world championships after thrashing South Korea 64-0. Hungary scored its 64 goals from 67 shots, with Rebecca Parkes scoring 11 goals. Song Ye-seo, who had South Korea's lone shot on goal in the first quarter, said, "[W]e'll try to do better next time."

column2: Vijender Singh remains unbeaten, wins 11th professional bout
column3: Indian boxer Vijender Singh continued his unbeaten run after clinching a Technical Knockout over Mike Snider, on his debut in the US professional circuit on Sunday. This is the 33-year-old's 11th consecutive victory in the circuit. "Vijender is a good boxer and I believe I underestimated his experience and technique," Snider said about Vijender.

column2: Mercedes' Hamilton wins record sixth British Grand Prix
column3: Mercedes' British driver Lewis Hamilton won a record sixth British Grand Prix at Silverstone on Sunday. Hamilton has surpassed record-holders Jim Clark and Alain Prost, who both had five wins in the British Grand Prix. Hamilton's Finnish partner Valtteri Bottas came in the second place while Ferrari's Charles Leclerc took the third spot.

column2: Chandrababu Naidu will go to jail for corruption: BJP Secy
column3: BJP National Secretary Sunil Deodhar on Sunday said former Andhra Pradesh Chief Minister Chandrababu Naidu will go to jail for corruption in two years. Deodhar further said that Chief Minister Jagan Mohan Reddy should send files on Naidu's corruption to CBI and ED for inquiry. "The theft should be brought to the notice of public and central government," Deodhar added.

column2: 4-year-old leopard rescued from well in Pune's Shirur Taluka
column3: A four-year-old leopard was rescued from a well by a team of Shirur Range Rescue and Wildlife SOS in Pune's Shirur Taluka on Sunday. The rescue team reached the spot after receiving information about the incident from a rescue volunteer of Shirur Range. The leopard was later shifted to Manikdoh Leopard Rescue Centre for preliminary treatment.

column2: Make mother tongue mandatory for primary schools: VP Naidu
column3: Vice President Venkaiah Naidu on Saturday said that every state government should make the medium of instruction in the mother tongue mandatory up to class 5 or 8. Naidu also suggested that state governments link employment with native languages so every officer is familiar with the local language. "Don't impose any language, but don't oppose any language too," Naidu said.

column2: I-T Dept snooping people's social media a misconception: CBDT
column3: The notion that Income Tax Department snoops people's spending patterns on social media platforms to find tax evaders is a "misconception", Central Board of Direct Taxes (CBDT) Chairman PC Mody said. "We already get to know actual...financial transactions of people from authentic sources," he said. However, he said CBDT has deployed a data analytics system to profile entities' transaction trail.

column2: Ed Sheeran confirms he is married to girlfriend Cherry Seaborn
column3: After months of speculation, singer Ed Sheeran has confirmed he's married to longtime girlfriend Cherry Seaborn. He revealed this while talking about the lyrics of 'Remember The Name' from his new album 'No.6 Collaborations Project'. Ed Sheeran said, "It was actually before me and Cherry got married, and I knew that we'd be married by the point...the song came out."

column2: A first in India: Akshay on women scientists leading Chandrayaan 2
column3: Akshay Kumar took to social media to wish the female scientists who are behind ISRO's Chandrayaan 2 mission. "India's second space mission to the moon, Chandrayaan 2 is led by two women scientists of Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO), a first in India's history. Sending my best to the rocket women and ISRO team, more power to you," he tweeted.

column2: British Army's parachute team delivers ball to umpires in WC final
column3: Red Devils, the British Army's Parachute Regiment display team, jumped from a helicopter and landed at the Lord's Cricket Ground to deliver match ball to umpires to mark the opening of 2019 World Cup final. "Not your standard match ball delivery method," wrote Cricket World Cup's official Instagram handle. Hosts England are bowling first in the final against New Zealand.

column2: ISRO asks people what they would take to Moon, shares responses
column3: Ahead of the launch of Chandrayaan 2, the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) asked people what they would like to take to the Moon. ISRO shared responses, with one person saying he would carry the Indian National Flag, a weighing machine and a smartphone. Another person said he would carry water from river Ganga and a DSLR with lens kit.

column2: 20-yr-old law student kills himself over harassment by friends in UP
column3: A 20-year-old law student allegedly committed suicide by hanging himself at his home in Uttar Pradesh's Ghaziabad after being harassed by his four friends. The deceased's father filed a police complaint. His father also gave police the deceased's mobile with a recorded video clip in which he alleged that his friends harassed him which led him to take his life.

column2: Govt to impose ₹10,000 penalty on misquoting Aadhaar number: Report
column3: The government will reportedly begin imposing a ₹10,000 penalty on individuals who fail to quote their Aadhaar number accurately in the documents related to high-value transactions from September 1, 2019. These transactions include buying a car or home, travelling overseas or making investments. A similar penalty may be imposed on the person supposed to authenticate the identification number.

column2: US Congresswoman's aide criticised for Subhas Chandra Bose t-shirt
column3: US Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez's Indian-American aide Saikat Chakrabarti is being criticised for wearing a t-shirt with Subhas Chandra Bose's image printed on it. Chakrabarti had appeared in a video wearing the t-shirt in December last year, but the video went viral recently after a controversy. Notably, Bose is seen by some as "an Indian nationalist who collaborated with the Nazis".

column2: Pakistan agrees to daily 5,000 Indian pilgrims on Kartarpur corridor
column3: Pakistan on Sunday agreed to build a bridge across zero line of the Kartarpur corridor to provide all-weather connectivity and allow 5,000 Sikh pilgrims to travel daily after the corridor becomes operational, an official said. "Pakistan also agreed for visa-free access for pilgrims," he added. India also handed over a copy of the notification banning pro-Khalistan outfit Sikhs for Justice.

column2: French Prez booed, told to step down ahead of Bastille Day parade
column3: French President Emmanuel Macron was booed by protestors who demanded his resignation as he arrived at the annual Bastille Day parade in Paris on Sunday. This comes just one day after the 'yellow vest' protestors took to the streets, marking the 35th consecutive week of the nationwide protest against the Macron-led government's policies.

column2: France to create space command within air force: Prez Macron
column3: French President Emmanuel Macron on Saturday said he approved the creation of a space command within the French air force to improve the country's defence capabilities. However, he said the investment involved was yet to be determined. Last year, US President Donald Trump's administration announced a plan to create a new 'Space Force' as the sixth branch of the military.

column2: Spoke up when Infosys' core values were thrown into dustbin: Murthy
column3: Talking about concerns expressed by him after retirement from Infosys, Co-founder Narayana Murthy said he spoke up when he saw core values of Infosys were being thrown into the "dustbin". "(In) 2014 CEO (Sikka) was given 55% hike on (salary of) $7 million...COO was given a 30% hike," said Murthy. "No middle-level fellow was given salary increase," he added.

column2: On the day of test you're not going to read many books: Federer
column3: Speaking ahead of his Wimbledon 2019 title clash against Novak Djokovic, Swiss tennis player Roger Federer said, "This is like a school. The day of the test, you're not going to read... many books that day." "It's been a rock-solid year... From that standpoint I can go into the match very confident," the eight-time Wimbledon champion said.

column2: Ashwin picks 6-for against Surrey in County C'ship match
column3: Indian spinner Ravichandran Ashwin, playing for Nottinghamshire, picked up a six-wicket haul against Surrey in the County Championship. Ashwin's performance helped Nottinghamshire dismiss Surrey for 240 on the first day. Nottinghamshire subsequently ended the day's play at 20/1. The second-best figures behind Ashwin's 6/69 were Liam Patterson-White's 3/62.

column2: Huawei plans extensive job cuts at US research unit: Report
column3: Chinese technology giant Huawei is planning extensive layoffs across its US-based research and development arm Futurewei Technologies, the Wall Street Journal reported. Hundreds of about 850 employees at the unit are reportedly expected to be laid off, with some Chinese staff being given an option to return to China staying within Huawei. The US had blacklisted Huawei over espionage allegations.

column2: There is a Disgusting Food Museum located in Sweden
column3: Disgusting Food Museum in Sweden has a display of "bizarre looking and smelling" food items. It features 80 foods from around the world, including frog smoothies from Peru, fruit bat soup, Iceland's shark meat and more. Visitors can also taste and smell some of the food items which are on display at the museum.

column2: 'Jugaad' govt demolishing itself: Naqvi on Karnataka crisis
column3: Amid the ongoing political crisis in Karnataka, Union Minister Mukhtar Abbas Naqvi said, the Congress had formed the government with "jugaad" which now appears to be demolishing itself due to internal conflicts. He added, "Let's see whether 'jugaad' will win or the people." On Saturday, five dissident MLAs approached the Supreme Court against Karnataka Speaker for not accepting their resignations.

column2: Satellite imagery startup Pixxel raises funding from growX, others
column3: Bengaluru-based early-stage spacetech startup Pixxel has raised an undisclosed pre-seed round of funding from growX ventures and angel investors such as Raju Reddy, Dileep Nath, Pawan Sarda and others. Pixxel was founded in late 2018 by Kshitij Khandelwal and Awais Ahmed, two undergraduates at BITS Pilani. Pixxel is building a constellation of nanosatellites for real-time satellite imagery.

column2: Delhi man stabbed to death for intervening in couple's fight
column3: A 20-year-old man was stabbed to death for intervening in his neighbour's fight with his wife in Delhi, police said on Saturday. The accused reportedly went to the victim's room later and stabbed him in his chest and thigh. The victim was declared brought dead at the hospital and police have nabbed the accused from his friend's house in Zamrudpur.

column2: RSS affiliate SJM urges PM to ban 'anti-national' app TikTok
column3: An RSS affiliate Swadeshi Jagran Manch (SJM) urged PM Narendra Modi to ban social media applications like 'TikTok' and 'Helo', claiming these applications have become a hub for "anti-national" content. It alleged that these apps were exposing India's youth to being influenced by "vested interests". It said these Chinese establishments have negative intentions with regards to India's "integrity".

column2: 20 drug suppliers held near educational institutes in Noida
column3: Twenty people were arrested on Saturday for their alleged involvement in drug trade near educational institutes in Noida and Greater Noida, police said. The police added that about 7.5 kg of marijuana, 5.8 kg of low-quality heroin, 1.3 kg of hashish were recovered from them. The arrests were made under the 13th edition of 'Operation Clean', the police said.

column2: Students forced to go home for toilet in UP school with no building
column3: Students of a government primary school in Uttar Pradesh's Shahjahanpur study in the open and reportedly go home to use the toilet or to drink water due to lack of infrastructure. "There is no space for cooking mid-day meal...the food is cooked at another school and...brought here," a teacher said. The school remains closed when it rains, the teacher added.

column2: Maharashtra woman throws daughters in well, attempts suicide
column3: A 30-year-old woman threw her six-month-old twin daughters into a well before jumping in herself in a bid to commit suicide in Maharashtra's Buldhana district on Saturday, said police. The incident occurred reportedly after the woman, named Shital Mohan Bhagat, got into an argument with her family. The toddlers drowned but Bhagat was pulled out and admitted to a hospital.

column2: 930 kids got ill after having mid-day meals in last 3 yrs: Govt
column3: The Ministry of Human Resource Development said that 930 children were reported ill and none of them died after consuming mid-day meals in the last three years. In the same period, the ministry received 35 complaints from 15 states and union territories about food quality. The overall responsibility for providing nutritious mid-day meals lies with state governments, an official said.

column2: J&J faces probe on denial of carcinogen in baby talc: Report
column3: The US Justice Department is now reportedly pursuing a criminal investigation into whether Johnson & Johnson (J&J) lied to public about cancer risks related to its 'Baby Powder'. Reports said a grand jury was examining documents about what J&J knew regarding any carcinogens in its products. A J&J spokesperson denied the new development, adding, "[It] doesn't contain asbestos...or cause cancer."

column2: JetPrivilege lets you book any seat, any flight, across airlines
column3: JetPrivilege now allows you to book flight tickets across 7000+ airlines worldwide. You can now earn JPMiles across these airlines only if booked on jetprivilege.com. As part of an exclusive offer, Earn 1000 Bonus JPMiles on your 1st flight booking today.

column2: Bigg Boss Telugu organisers asked how I'll satisfy the boss: Journo
column3: A Hyderabad-based female journalist, who was nominated for the third season of Bigg Boss Telugu, has alleged that the organisers asked for sexual favours in exchange for being selected for the final round. "They...asked me how I'm going to satisfy the boss. They also body-shamed me," the journalist claimed. A case has been registered against four members of the show.

column2: As actor, I should be allowed to play any person, tree, animal: Scarlett
column3: Hollywood actress Scarlett Johansson, while speaking about withdrawing from playing a transgender following criticism, said, "You know, as an actor I should be allowed to play any person, or any tree, or any animal because that is my job and the requirements of my job." She added that art should be "free of restrictions".

column2: Why would I watch the film again: 'Arjun Reddy' actor on 'Kabir Singh'
column3: 'Arjun Reddy' actor Vijay Deverakonda, when asked if he has seen the film's remake 'Kabir Singh' starring Shahid Kapoor, said, "I know the story, I have done that film, why will I watch again?" "Shahid has done that film, and he has gone through the character, and there is nothing for me to watch again," he added.

column2: All World Cup finals at Lord's have been won by team that lost toss
column3: Lord's Cricket Ground in London, which will be hosting 2019 World Cup final between England and New Zealand today, has previously hosted four World Cup finals (1975, 1979, 1983 and 1999). In each of those four finals, the team that lost the toss went on to win the match. Team batting first emerged victorious in three of the four matches.

column2: Williamson registers most runs by a captain in a World Cup edition
column3: New Zealand skipper Kane Williamson has set the record for most runs by a captain in World Cup history. The 28-year-old took his tally of runs in 2019 World Cup to 549 after opening his account against England in the final on Sunday, breaking the record set by Sri Lanka's Mahela Jayawardene, who aggregated 548 runs in 2007 World Cup.

column2: How have England and NZ fared in their previous World Cup finals?
column3: Prior to 2019 World Cup, England had reached three World Cup finals and New Zealand had reached one World Cup final. England lost 1979 final to West Indies by 92 runs, while Australia and Pakistan defeated them in the 1987 and 1992 finals by 7 and 22 runs respectively. Australia defeated New Zealand in the 2015 final by 7 wickets.

column2: Dharmasena only World Cup champ to take field in 2019 World Cup final
column3: Ex-Sri Lanka off-spinner Kumar Dharmasena is the only World Cup champion to take the field in 2019 World Cup final between England and New Zealand. The 48-year-old umpire, who will officiate the match, was in Sri Lanka's squad that won World Cup in 1996. None of the players in New Zealand and England sides have won a World Cup before.

column2: TV show 'Startup ki Baat' to air on DD National every Sunday
column3: As a part of Startup India initiative, a new television show on startups, 'Startup ki Baat', will air on DD National every Sunday. Startups will share their entrepreneurial journey on the show once in a week. The development comes a week after Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced a dedicated TV programme for startups while presenting the Union Budget 2019.

column2: After 41-year legal battle, man found not guilty of stealing ₹20
column3: After 41 years of legal battle over alleged theft of ₹20, a man was relieved of the charges in a Lok Adalat held in Gwalior on Saturday. The complainant Babulal, who is now 61-years-old said Ismail Khan, now aged 68, had stolen ₹20 from his pocket in 1978 when he was standing in a queue to purchase a bus ticket.

column2: 7 UP policemen injured while arresting man accused of cow smuggling
column3: Seven policemen were injured in an attack by villagers when they went to arrest a man wanted for cow smuggling in Uttar Pradesh's Prayagraj district. "Strict action will be taken and those involved in the attack will be arrested soon," said Ashutosh Mishra, SP Crime, Prayagraj. A large number of police personnel were deployed in the village after the incident.

column2: RBI plans app to help visually challenged identify currency notes
column3: The Reserve Bank of India is planning to come up with a mobile application to help visually challenged people to identify currency notes. The app would be able to identify the denomination of notes by capturing the image of the notes placed in front of the mobile camera. It will also generate an "audio notification" of the currency note denomination.

column2: Former Bangladesh military ruler Ershad dies aged 89
column3: Former Bangladesh military ruler Hussain Muhammad Ershad died on Sunday aged 89 following age-related health complications. Ershad had been on life support for 10 days in a military hospital in the capital Dhaka. He had seized power in a coup in 1982, overthrowing the then President Abdus Sattar. Ershad declared himself President in 1983.

column2: Ex-UK envoy to US said Trump left Iran deal to offend Obama: Report
column3: Former UK envoy to the US Kim Darroch had said that US President Donald Trump abandoned the 2015 Iran nuclear deal to "spite (offend) his predecessor Barack Obama", according to a report by the Daily Mail. Darroch described the US withdrawal as an act of "diplomatic vandalism". Darroch resigned from the post earlier this week.

column2: Australia ignore Glenn Maxwell, Marcus Stoinis for Ashes 2019
column3: Australia have excluded all-rounders Glenn Maxwell and Marcus Stoinis from a 25-player squad for an intra-Australia clash that will help in deciding the final squad for the upcoming Ashes 2019. The 25-member list has seven players from the World Cup campaign, 15 from the Australia A squad touring England and pacer Peter Siddle, batsmen Cameron Bancroft and Marnus Labuschagne.

column2: Jacques Kallis steps down as Kolkata Knight Riders head coach
column3: South African all-rounder Jacques Kallis has stepped down as the head coach of the Indian Premier League outfit Kolkata Knight Riders. "After nine fantastic years with KKR since 2011, as a player, mentor and Head Coach, it's time to explore new opportunities...I would to like to thank the owners, management and fellow players for many happy memories," Kallis wrote.

column2: Cabal-Farah 1st Colombians to win Grand Slam men's doubles title
column3: Juan Sebastian Cabal and Robert Farah became the first Colombians to win a Grand Slam men's doubles title on Saturday. They beat France's Nicolas Mahut and Edouard Roger-Vasselin 6-7 (5), 7-6 (5), 7-6 (6), 6-7 (5), 6-3 in a Wimbledon final that clocked just under 5 hours. A part of the match was played under the closed Centre Court roof.

column2: Cong ready to settle demands of rebel MLAs: DK Shivakumar
column3: Amid the ongoing political crisis in Karnataka, Congress leader DK Shivakumar said that the party is ready to settle the demands of the rebel MLAs. He added that the MLAs know the law and if they vote against confidence motion in the Assembly, then they'll lose their membership. Shivakumar further said, "We're getting signals that they will save our government."

column2: Yulu in talks to raise funds from Xiaomi arm, others: Report
column3: Bengaluru-based cycle sharing platform Yulu is reportedly in advanced talks to raise a Series A round of ₹100 crore ($15 million) from Chinese investors including Xiaomi's venture capital arm Shunwei Capital. Former InMobi Chief Business Officer Atul Satija is also expected to participate in the round. Yulu has reportedly already received commitments from its existing investors including Blume Ventures.

column2: Muslim barbers refuse haircuts to Dalits in UP village
column3: The Dalit community in Uttar Pradesh's Pipalsana village has alleged that Muslim barbers are refusing them haircuts. An incident had occurred between the two groups earlier following which barbers refused to cut their hair, an official said. The barbers reportedly closed their shops following police mediation and a case has been registered against three people.

column2: 5,000 Bihar villages to be digitally equipped: Prasad
column3: Union Minister Ravi Shankar Prasad said that 5,000 villages of Bihar will be digitally equipped through Wi-Fi and other online services in future. He added that there are 297 IT and BPO centres operational in 120 small towns and cities across the country. Prasad said, eight BPO centres are operational in Patna, while one such facility is functional at Muzaffarpur.

column2: NIA arrests 2 from Tamil Nadu for suspected terror links
column3: The National Investigation Agency (NIA) has arrested two persons with suspected terror links from Tamil Nadu on Saturday. The NIA accused the two of collecting funds and planning terror attacks in India with "the intention to establish Islamic rule". The anti-terror agency recovered nine mobile phones, 15 SIM cards, three laptops and other items during the bust.

column2: China holds military drills after Taiwan buys arms from US
column3: China's military recently carried out air and naval drills along its southeast coast following the latest arms sales from the US to Taiwan. Earlier, China said it would impose sanctions on US firms involved in a deal to sell $2.2 billion worth of tanks, missiles and related equipment to Taiwan, saying it harmed China's sovereignty and national security.

column2: RBI reports failed to mention potential IL&FS crisis: Ex-CEA
column3: Former Chief Economic Adviser Arvind Subramanian has said that the RBI's Financial Stability Reports in last four-five years failed to mention the potential liquidity crisis at Infrastructure Leasing & Financial Services (IL&FS). "While RBI is one of the best institutions...We had some massive failures like IL&FS," he said. The IL&FS Group has a debt burden of nearly ₹1 lakh crore.

column2: DHFL reports ₹2,223 cr loss in Q4, warns it may not survive
column3: Dewan Housing Finance (DHFL) on Saturday reported a ₹2,223-crore standalone net loss in the quarter ended March, saying it's undergoing "substantial financial stress". DHFL said consistent credit-rating downgrades have impaired its ability to raise funds, possibly raising "doubts on its ability to continue as a going concern". Despite this, DHFL is taking active steps to monetise assets, it added.

column2: You will be a mother by your next birthday: Ambani wishes Shloka
column3: India's richest man Mukesh Ambani wished his daughter-in-law Shloka Mehta a happy birthday in a video. "By the time I wish you next year, not only will I be a grandfather but you will be a mother, so this is an eventful year," Ambani said. The video also featured wishes from Isha Ambani, Anand Piramal and Anant Ambani among others.

column2: Sidhu resigns as Punjab minister, shares letter written to Rahul
column3: Navjot Singh Sidhu has resigned as Minister from the Punjab Cabinet. Sidhu on Sunday took to Twitter to share his resignation letter dated June 10 that he had submitted to the then Congress President Rahul Gandhi. This comes after Punjab Chief Minister Amarinder Singh in June divested Sidhu of his Local Government and Tourism and Cultural Affairs portfolios.

column2: Balasaheb Thorat replaces Ashok Chavan as Maharashtra Cong Chief
column3: Balasaheb Thorat was appointed as the president of the Congress' Maharashtra unit on Saturday, replacing Ashok Chavan who resigned in May. Thorat has served as Minister of Revenue and Khar Lands in the State government. Nitin Raut, Baswaraj M Patil, Vishwajeet Kadam, Yashomati Chandrakant Thakur and Muzaffer Hussain have been named the new working presidents.

column2: Jasprit Bumrah reacts to fan's elderly mother imitating his action
column3: After a video of a fan's elderly mother imitating Jasprit Bumrah's bowling action went viral, the Team India fast bowler took to Twitter to react to it. "This made my day," the 25-year-old wrote. "Just like rest of us...the mothership was so impressed with Bumrah's performance in World Cup that she decided to mimic his run-up," the fan had tweeted.

column2: When was the last time a team won the World Cup for the first time?
column3: Cricket World Cup will get first-time winners after New Zealand and England face each other in 2019 World Cup final on Sunday. The last time a team won World Cup for the first time was on March 17, 1996, when Sri Lanka defeated Australia in the final in Lahore. Pakistan won the World Cup for the first time in 1992.

column2: What will happen if 2019 WC final ends in a tie or gets washed out?
column3: If England-New Zealand final ends in a tie, a Super Over will be used to determine the winner. The group stage standings or Net Run Rate will count for nothing. In case, the match gets washed out today, it'll be played on reserve day tomorrow. England and New Zealand will be declared joint-winners if reserve day also gets washed out.

column2: Computer password inventor Fernando Corbató passes away at 93
column3: US-born Fernando José "Corby" Corbató, credited with inventing the computer password, passed away in Massachusetts at the age of 93. Corbató led the development of the Compatible Time-Sharing System (CTSS), regarded as one of the world's first operating systems. It allowed multiple people to use a computer at the same time.

column2: Will release tanker if Iran guarantees it won't travel to Syria: UK
column3: British foreign minister Jeremy Hunt has said the UK would facilitate the release of the detained Iranian oil tanker if the Middle East nation gave guarantees it would not go to Syria. The tanker was seized last week by British Royal Marines off the coast of the British Mediterranean territory of Gibraltar on suspicion of violating sanctions against Syria.

column2: 50 killed as monsoon rains cause floods, landslides in Nepal
column3: Flash floods and landslides in Nepal triggered by monsoon rains have killed 50 people while 33 others have gone missing, officials said. Officials added that the Kosi river in eastern Nepal, which flows into the state of Bihar, had risen above the danger mark. Nepal's security forces have been deployed to assist ongoing search and rescue operations.

column2: Rising intolerance, hate crimes can damage India's growth: Godrej
column3: Godrej Group Chairman Adi Godrej has said that rising intolerance, social instability, hate crimes, violence against women, moral policing, caste and religion-based violence can "seriously damage" India's economic growth. "It's not all a rosy picture now. One must not lose sight of the massive (impoverishment) plaguing our nation which can...prevent us from realising our potential," he added.

column2: World Bank court orders Pak to pay $5.8 billion to Tethyan Copper
column3: A World Bank arbitration court has ordered the Pakistani government to pay damages of $5.8 billion to Tethyan Copper. The company discovered vast mineral wealth more than a decade ago in Pakistan's Reko Diq. Tethyan said it had invested more than $220 million by the time Pakistan, in 2011, refused to grant them the mining lease needed to keep operating.

column2: Allahabad Bank reports ₹1,775 crore fraud by Bhushan Power & Steel
column3: The Allahabad Bank on Saturday said it reported fraud of ₹1,775 crore by bankrupt steelmaker Bhushan Power & Steel. "(Bhushan) has misappropriated bank funds, manipulated books of accounts to raise funds from banks," Allahabad Bank said. On July 6, state-run Punjab National Bank (PNB) said it had reported an alleged fraud of ₹3,805 crore in Bhushan's accounts.

column2: Ex-India wicketkeeper Kiran More named USA's interim coach
column3: Former India wicketkeeper Kiran More has been appointed as the interim coach of USA's senior national team. The 56-year-old has been named alongside advisors including James Pamment, the Mumbai Indians fielding coach, former Australia assistant coach David Saker and former Indian players Pravin Amre and Sunil Joshi. Gujarat-born More played 94 ODI's and 49 Test matches for India.

column2: Microsoft to end Hearts, Spades net games for Windows XP, ME, 7
column3: Microsoft is ending its internet games including Hearts, Spades, Checkers, Backgammon, MSN Go and Reversi from Windows version XP, ME and 7. While these Microsoft Internet Games services on Windows XP and ME will end on July 31, 2019, they'll end for Windows 7 on January 22, 2020. Microsoft said it's doing so to invest resources towards more recent technologies.

column2: Human-mirroring robot mastered #BottleCapChallenge, says MIT
column3: MIT's Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Lab (CSAIL) has shared a video of its RoboRaise robot, saying it has "mastered" a new skill, the bottle cap challenge. The RoboRaise mirrors a human by copying the movement through data collected from a person's hand. The muscle activity is monitored using electromyography (EMG) sensors on a user's biceps and triceps, MIT revealed.

column2: 107 TMC, Cong, CPI(M) MLAs will join BJP in WB: Mukul Roy
column3: BJP leader Mukul Roy on Saturday claimed that a total of 107 West Bengal MLAs from TMC, Congress and CPI(M) will join the saffron party soon. He further said, "We've their list prepared and they are in contact with us." However, on Saturday, nine councillors of the Kanchrapara Municipality, who had defected to the BJP, returned to the TMC.

column2: India needs to create more 'agripreneurs': Anurag Thakur
column3: The Minister of State for Finance Anurag Thakur has said the rural startup ecosystem needs to be strengthened to encourage rural startups by rural youth. "Agri-based e-commerce platforms, farm monitoring, linking with fintech will help youth become 'agripreneurs'," he added. Thakur was speaking at the National Bank For Agriculture & Rural Development's (NABARD) 38th Foundation Day's inauguration.

column2: 5 arrested with illicit liquor in Bihar's Gaya
column3: The Excise Department arrested five persons in possession of illicit liquor in separate cases in Bihar's Gaya on Saturday. The arrests were made as a part of a special drive conducted to curb the sale of illicit liquor in the region, police said. In addition to liquor, police have also seized three two-wheelers, two cars and mobile phones from them.

column2: 2 Maoists, with ₹5 lakh reward, shot down in Chhattisgarh
column3: Two Maoists, with ₹5 lakh reward on their heads, were gunned down in an encounter with security forces in Chhattisgarh's Dantewada district on Sunday, police said. Dantewada Superintendent of Police said that a woman Maoist was also arrested. Police said that a senior Maoist leader of Malangir area committee of CPI (Maoist) is trapped in the ongoing encounter.

column2: 60 cartons of illicit liquor seized in UP's Etah
column3: The Uttar Pradesh Police on Saturday seized as many as 60 cartons of illicit liquor from Etah district. According to the police, the illicit liquor has been recovered from the smugglers during checking in Sakit area in the district while two accused smugglers fled the spot. On July 13, the Excise Department in Bihar arrested five people with illicit liquor.

column2: Man with ₹7L worth hashish in slippers held at Kerala airport
column3: Central Industrial Security Force personnel apprehended a Doha-bound passenger, who was allegedly carrying hashish estimated to be worth ₹7 lakh, from Kerala's Kannur International Airport. Officials said that upon frisking and intensive screening, they recovered around 900 grams of the hashish from the man's pelvic area and the slippers. Officials handed over the man to Narcotics Control Bureau.

column2: 50-yr-old teacher held for raping 4-yr-old in Punjab school
column3: A 50-year-old school teacher was arrested on Saturday for allegedly raping a four-year-old girl inside the school premises in Punjab, police said. In her complaint, the victim's mother said that her daughter informed her that the teacher sexually assaulted her and that her blood-stained clothes were washed by a school maid. The police also arrested the maid for destroying evidence.

column2: 15 policemen injured in bus accident in Jharkhand
column3: At least 15 policemen of the Jharkhand Armed Police were injured after the bus in which they were travelling met with an accident, officials said. The incident occurred when the bus driver lost control while taking a steep turn and dashed against the sidewalls of the rock, officials added. The policemen were rushed to a hospital for treatment.

column2: Was Dhoni run-out on no-ball in World Cup semi-final vs New Zealand?
column3: A small graphic showing six players outside the 30-yard circle ahead of delivery on which MS Dhoni got run-out against New Zealand semi-final had gone viral. However, only five fielders are allowed outside the circle in the third powerplay. The graphic was a broadcasting error as Lockie Ferguson had called up a fielder inside the circle before bowling the delivery.

column2: Dhoni dropped Yuvraj, Gambhir, Sehwag using his influence: Yograj
column3: Former India all-rounder Yuvraj Singh's father Yograj Singh has said that MS Dhoni dropped Yuvraj Singh, Gautam Gambhir and Virender Sehwag using his influence. "He reasoned their fielding and fitness for dropping," he added. "Why did we lose 2015 World Cup semi-final? Because of Dhoni. Why did we lose 2019 World Cup semi-final? Again because of Dhoni," he further said.

column2: Always admired your calmness and self belief: Gilchrist to Dhoni
column3: Following India's 18-run defeat against New Zealand in the 2019 World Cup semi-final, former Australia wicketkeeper Adam Gilchrist tweeted a message for former India captain MS Dhoni. "Not sure if you are playing on but thanks @msdhoni You have given the game so much. Always admired your calmness and self belief," wrote Gilchrist.

column2: Ravindra Jadeja was inconsolable after India's loss: Wife Rivaba
column3: All-rounder Ravindra Jadeja's wife Rivaba has revealed that her husband was inconsolable after losing the 2019 World Cup semi-final. "He kept saying, 'If I wouldn't have got out, we could've won'," she added. "When you lose a match after coming this close, it really hurts and it'll be a while before he comes to terms with it," she further said.

column2: It wasn't meant to be: David Warner after Australia's World Cup exit
column3: After Australia lost to England in the 2019 World Cup semi-final, opener David Warner took to Instagram to share pictures from Australia's World Cup campaign and wrote, "It wasn’t meant to be!" "We gave it our best but came up a little short. Will take some great memories away from this World Cup," he added.

column2: First-ever image of quantum entanglement unveiled
column3: Glasgow University physicists have unveiled the first-ever image capturing quantum entanglement, or "Bell entanglement", depicting two photons interacting and sharing physical states for an instant. A pair of photons were shot from a laser, split and sent on separate paths before being captured by a special camera. The image shows the photons mirroring each other to form a ring shape.

column2: Teen accused of making vulgar calls to 40 female Rajasthan professors
column3: Jaipur Police on Friday detained a teenager from Haryana's Hisar for allegedly making lewd internet-generated calls to around 40 women professors of Rajasthan University. According to the police statement, the accused used the Wi-Fi connection of a university where his father is a professor, to make those lewd calls. He allegedly got the professors' phone numbers from Rajasthan University's website.

column2: Man gives wife's police uniform to girlfriend to loot people, both held
column3: A woman was arrested along with her boyfriend for committing robberies by impersonating a police officer in Madhya Pradesh's Indore. The boyfriend had given a police uniform of his wife, who is posted as an inspector in Madhya Pradesh Police. Police also seized a fake police identity card from the accused.

column2: Man dies as Kolkata Metro takes off with his hand stuck in door
column3: Sajal Kanjilal, a middle-aged man, died after his hand got stuck between the gates of a metro train in Kolkata on Saturday. Sajal was trying to board the overcrowded AC coach but the automatic door closed while his arm was inside the train. The man died after falling on the tracks after the first four bogies left the platform.

column2: Head constable beaten to death with rods, sticks by mob in Rajasthan
column3: Abdul Gani, a head constable posted at Bhim Police Station of Rajsamand district of Rajasthan was allegedly beaten to death by a mob on Saturday. The 45-year-old was allegedly attacked with sticks and rods in Brar area of Bhim, where he had gone to investigate a land dispute case. Gani's postmortem will be conducted on Sunday, a police official said.

column2: Anand Mahindra confirms Super 30 teacher refused his donation offer
column3: Billionaire Anand Mahindra has confirmed that Anand Kumar, Founder of 'Super 30' coaching programme, "courteously" declined his offer for financial support when he met him. "I remain an admirer of how he's changed the lives of so many," Mahindra added. "Our Prime Minister...tycoons like Mukesh Ambani or Anand Mahindra have offered donation but I haven't accepted anything," Kumar had said.

column2: Top executive of Future Group arrested over ₹14 cr unpaid duties
column3: The Directorate of Revenue Intelligence has arrested CFO of Future Enterprises, part of Kishore Biyani's Future Group, for alleged customs duty evasion of ₹14.58 crore on garment imports. Dinesh Maheshwari was held for "misuse" of duty-free imports facility from Bangladesh under a free trade agreement. The imports were allegedly being supplied from other countries but directed through Bangladesh.

column2: Those calling me chor are losers: Mallya on pic posted by Gayle
column3: After being trolled over a picture with Chris Gayle, Vijay Mallya said those calling him chor (thief) are losers. "Ask...banks to take their full money that I'm offering for the past one year. Then decide on who is chor," he added. Mallya was recently granted permission by a London court to appeal the UK's decision to extradite him to India.

column2: Weightlifter Pardeep wins gold; sets Commonwealth record
column3: Indian weightlifter Pardeep Singh on Saturday set a new record and went on to win a gold medal at the Commonwealth Championships in Apia. Pardeep, who competed in the 109 kg category, broke the record in the clean and jerk category by lifting 202 kg. Two-time Commonwealth Games medallist Vikas Thakur won silver medal in the men's 96 kg event.

column2: India women's football team jumps 6 spots to 57 in FIFA rankings
column3: The Indian women's football team jumped six places to reach the 57th spot in the latest FIFA team rankings. Among the Asian countries, the Indian women's team is ranked 11th.
